page.title: 01The Village of New Deer
page.content: The bulk of the village consists of houses and byres along each side of the 1km Main St/High St which was a {"Model Village"}constructed by its principal landlord, probably in the 17th century. Behind each property are small fields which belonged to these crofts. The sight of cattle being driven down High St each day finally disappeared in the late 70's. Fordyce Terrace (named after the lairds of Brucklay),is the main road from Maud and connects Main St to the junction with the Turriff-Aberdeen road which, together with Gladstone Terr and Kirkbrae Terr, is a remnant of the older village of{Auchreddie, remembered in the names of streets and local farms. Newer houses are to be found near the park at the Eastern end of the village and on individual sites round about.
